O.AeB./l95.merit.)iGeneral Headquarters,British Armies in France^'7th May, 1913.Sir, .I have the honour to forward herewith reports received from the G.O.C., Royal Air Force, on the bombing raid carried out by the Ochey Squadrons on the 3rd May, 1918.I have the honour to be, Sir,Your obedient Servant,The Secretary, War Officet London, S.W.(Sd,) K. Wigram,for Field-Marshal, Commanding- in-Chi-ef, British Armies in France,* DETAILED REPORT ON BOMB RAID CARRIED OUT 3rd MAY, 1916,12 De Havilland 4s 0 left at 8.5 a,un to "bomb the Railway Station and Sidings at Thionville* The objective was reached and 24 - 112 lb, bombs were dropped from 12,500 feet.Several bursts were seen on the Railway Station, three on the Railway South of the Bridge, three on the Railway South of the Station, four in the Sidings and many bursts round about the Station and on the lines.. One burst was seen in the Gas Works y and three bombs were seen to burst on the Carlshutte V/orks.A total of S3 plates were exposed with excellent results, showing a considerable number of bombs bursting on the objectiveAll machines returned safely at 11^35 aamaAnti-aircraft fire was moderate and several enemy aircraft were seen, who, however, did not attack. The sky was clear with no clouds.Two successful Photographic Reconnaissances were carried out, a total of 52 plates being exposed. The photographs were excellent and photographs of several Hostile Aerodromes were secured.(Sd.) R.A. Prout,'Major S.O.2.In the Field. for Brigadier-General,G.O.C., 8th Brigade, 4th May, 1918.
